title: Subjective Probability: A Judgment of Representativeness

studies.study_name: Similarity of Sample to Population: Birth Sequences

findings.main_hypothesis: The subjective probability of a sample is determined by its similarity to the population proportion; sequences that deviate from the population ratio (0.50) are judged less likely.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Number of participants judging BGBBBB as less likely than GBGBBG > 50%

original_data_points.description: Comparison of birth sequences GBGBBG (given frequency 72) and BGBBBB.

findings.main_hypothesis: The subjective probability of a sample is determined by how well it reflects the randomness of the generating process; ordered sequences are judged less likely than disordered ones.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Sequence BBBGGG is judged less likely than GBBGBG

original_data_points.description: Comparison of perceived randomness in birth sequences.

findings.main_hypothesis: People judge a sample to belong to a population if the sample proportion is more representative of that population's majority/minority status, even when the distance to both population means is equal.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Participants guess Program A (majority) more often than Program B (minority) for a 55% sample.

original_data_points.description: Guessing program origin for a class with 55% boys (Program A: 65% boys; Program B: 45% boys).

findings.main_hypothesis: Experts believe in the 'Law of Small Numbers,' overestimating the likelihood that a significant result in a small sample will be replicated in an even smaller sample.

original_data_points.description: Subjective probability of replication (n=10) after initial significant result (n=20, p < .05).

findings.main_hypothesis: Distributions that appear more 'random' or 'uniform' are judged more likely than those that appear perfectly symmetric or patterned, even if the latter are objectively more probable.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Distribution I (4,4,5,4,3) is judged more likely than Distribution II (4,4,4,4,4).

original_data_points.description: Comparison of two marble distributions among five children.

findings.main_hypothesis: Subjective sampling distributions are independent of sample size (N-invariance), as sample size is not a representative property of the population.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Distributions for N=10, N=100, and N=1000 are identical.

original_data_points.description: Subjective sampling distributions for three populations across three sample sizes.

findings.main_hypothesis: Posterior odds are determined by the representativeness of the sample mean rather than the sample size, leading to higher confidence in smaller, more extreme samples.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Subjective odds for Case (i) > Subjective odds for Case (ii)

original_data_points.description: Odds that a sample came from a male vs female population based on height.

overall_original_results.description: Consolidated numerical findings across all representativeness and sample size studies.

data_tables.table_name: Study 7: Ordinal Judgments of Sample Size (N=97)
